awd_titl_txt: BBSRC-NSF/BIO:  Understanding the origin and evolution of metabolic interactions using synthetic microbial communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial communities are critically important for many environmental processes such as the release of nutrients from the degradation of dead organic matter.  Microbial communities are also important for health, as beneficial microbes help digest food, modulate immunity, and fend off intruding pathogens.  Each species of microbe in the community uses certain compounds available in the environment and often the microbes release new compounds that other members of the community can use.  These "metabolic interactions" impact the survival of individual species and the stability of the microbial community as a whole. The goal of this collaborative project is to better understand how these interactions develop and change depending on the environment and microbial species in the community, and how these interactions change the stability and composition of the communities.  Ultimately, this project aims to reveal principles for the design of microbial communities for purposes such environmental remediation.  Participants on this project will include high school teachers, underrepresented minority high school students, and underrepresented minority undergraduates.  

Microbial communities are ubiquitous, and are critical players in mediating host health and disease and in the cycling of elements in ecosystems.  Metabolic interactions between species impact community function and stability.  However, the emergence and evolution of metabolic interactions is poorly understood.  The laboratories involved in this project will take advantage of tractable synthetic yeast communities and mathematical modeling to experimentally and theoretically study the origin and evolution of metabolic interactions.  They will undertake a fully integrated, collaborative approach that combines the expertise of both groups on metabolic modeling, synthetic biology, and microbial ecology and evolution.  First, statistical thermodynamics and differential equations will be used to model metabolic overflows.  Next, metabolic overflows as well as key cellular parameters will be experimentally characterized using targeted metabolomics, fluorescence microscopy, and single cell electrochemical measurements. These experimental measurements will be used to constrain, test, and refine the model.  The tested model will be embedded within an in silico evolution framework to simulate evolution, and to predict how initial community conditions (e.g. nutrient environment, genotypes, and species interactions) might affect the evolution of new metabolic interactions.  Finally, model predictions will be tested by evolving synthetic yeast communities from different starting conditions in chemostats and turbidostats, and emerging metabolic interactions will be characterized.

This collaborative US/UK project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the UK Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

(i) Sulfur-mediated metabolic interactions between microbes: Metabolic interactions play a fundamental role in determining the composition and function of microbial communities. Understanding how these interactions emerge and evolve is key to understanding natural communities and constructing synthetic ones. We found that when the coupling between nutrient availability and growth is perturbed in the budding yeast S. cerevisiae, sulfur-containing metabolites such as glutathione and glutathione conjugates are excreted, which in turn promotes the evolution of mutants that rely on these metabolites to grow (Green & Sonal et al., PLoS Biology 2020). Strikingly, we found that hydrogen sulfide, a gas released as an intermediate of sulfur metabolism, can trigger a novel metabolic pathway in S. cerevisiae, and we have characterized the molecular mechanisms of this pathway (Sonal et al., to be submitted in 2023). 

(ii) Artificial selection of microbial communities: Multispecies microbial communities often display community functions (e.g. sewage digestion, cheese fermentation) arising from species interactions. Interactions are often difficult to decipher, making it challenging to design communities with desired functions. Alternatively, similar to artificial selection for individuals in agriculture, one could repeatedly choose communities with the highest functions to reproduce by randomly partitioning each into multiple Newborn communities for the next cycle. However, previous efforts have often encountered difficulties. Using computer simulations, we have identified various failure modes, and predicted effective strategies (e.g. Xie & Shou, Nat Comm 2021). We have also established a theoretical framework to shed light on a key aspect of community selection - the inheritance of community trait from parent to offspring (Xie & Shou, to be submitted in 2023).

(iii) Statistical analysis of time series data: In disciplines from biology to climate science, a routine task is to compute a correlation between a pair of time series, and determine whether the correlation is statistically significant (i.e. unlikely under the null hypothesis that the time series are independent). This task is especially challenging since time series typically exhibit autocorrelation, which renders standard statistical tests invalid. We have written an accessible and critical synthesis of three popular approaches (pairwise correlation, Granger causality, and state space reconstruction), and for each approach, we ask what it tests for, what causal statement (if any) it might imply, and when it could lead us astray (Yuan & Shou, eLife 2022). Using simulated time series data from species engaging in known interactions, we show that the choice of statistic and the method for generating the null distribution can both affect false positive and true positive rates (Cannistra et al., to be submitted in 2023). Finally, we have devised two new methods for testing statistical dependence between two time series. The Truncated Time Shift (TTS) test can be mathematically proven to yield a correct false positive rate under the minimally restrictive condition, is versatile (i.e. can be used with any correlation statistic), and when applied toFuture: Power has three aspects: consistency: power tending to 1 when data approaching infinity; efficiency: how fast power increases with data; universal: TTS will have trouble for if shifted correlation plot has a period of below 1/alpha; to generate this, one can use periodic systems with a period below 1/alpha. data sets from climatology, animal behavior and microbiome science, discovered new dependence relationships in addition to known ones (Yuan & Shou, bioRxiv 2022, to be resubmitted in 2023). The Permute-Match test is designed to test dependence between nonstationary time series from a small number of replicates, and improves the detection power of the standard permute test while guaranteeing the false positive rate (Yuan & Shou, bioRxiv 2023, to be submitted in 2023).

 

Broad Impact:

Budding yeast is a widely employed model system and a popular organism for biotechnology and food fermentation. Discovering novel aspects of sulfide metabolism will broaden our understanding of this workhorse organism, as well as potentially impact its application in wine fermentation where sulfide contamination is an important concern. A novel hydrogen sulfie-responsive pathway can serve as a module for designing synthetic microbial communities to facilitate bioremediation by neutralizing hydrogen sulfide.

Microbial communities perform important functions, ranging from sewage treatment to modulating human health and diseases. Additionally, synthetic communities can be engineered to, for example, turn agriculture wastes to biofuels or pharmaceuticals. Thus, our work on how to effectively improve community function will have a wide-ranging impact.

The capacity to sequence DNA has undergone a revolution. Consequently, an increasing number of studies use sequencing to quantify microbial abundance over time in, for example, a human body. Devising methods to extract information from these time series data can help scientists formulate accurate hypotheses, and experimentally testing these hypotheses will generate information on how microbial communities work. This knowledge will in turn guide the design of effective communities for fighting pathogens or promoting human health.
